--Word--|wind |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|The perceptible natural movement of the air, especially in the form of a current of air blowing from a particular direction.|Used in reference to an impending situation.|The rush of air caused by a fast-moving body.|A scent carried by the wind, indicating the presence or proximity of an animal or person.|Breath as needed in physical exertion, speech, etc., or the power of breathing without difficulty in such situations.|Air swallowed while eating or gas generated in the stomach and intestines by digestion.|Empty, pompous, or boastful talk; meaningless rhetoric.|Wind instruments, or specifically woodwind instruments, forming a band or a section of an orchestra.|Cause (someone) to have difficulty breathing because of exertion or a blow to the stomach.|Make (a baby) bring up wind after feeding by patting its back.|Detect the presence of (a person or animal) by scent.|Sound (a bugle or call) by blowing.|--Examples--|the wind howled about the building|an easterly wind|gusts of wind|he had seen which way the wind was blowing|he waited while Jez got his wind back|she hit the floor with a thud that knocked the wind out of her|these passages are most suitable for wind alone|wind players|the fall nearly winded him|Paddy's wife handed him their six-month-old daughter to be winded|the birds could not have seen us or winded us|but scarce again his horn he wound|

before the ball is put into play.|Each of two or more recurring periods in which different groups of workers do the same jobs in relay.|The group of people who work during a particular shift.|A --Word--|wing |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|(in a bird) a modified forelimb that bears large feathers and is used for flying.|(in a bat or pterosaur) a modified forelimb with skin stretched between or behind the fingers.|(in most insects) each of two or four flat extensions of the thoracic cuticle, either transparent or covered in scales.|The wing of a bird as food.|Used with reference to ease and swiftness of movement.|A rigid horizontal structure that projects from both sides of an aircraft and supports it in the air.|A pilot's certificate of ability to fly a plane, indicated by a badge representing a pair of wings.|A raised part of the body of a car or other vehicle above the wheel.|A part of a large building, especially one that projects from the main part.|A group within a political party or other organization having particular views or a particular function.|The sides of a theatre stage out of view of the audience.|(in soccer, rugby, and hockey) the part of the field close to the sidelines.|An attacking player positioned near to one of the sidelines.|A lateral part or projection of an organ or structure.|A thin membranous appendage of a fruit or seed that is dispersed by the wind.|An air force unit of several squadrons or groups.|The right or left flank of the main body of a battle formation.|A flock of plovers (birds)|Travel on wings or by aircraft; improvise.|--Examples--|the thought gave wings to her feet|Michael earned his wings as a commercial pilot|a maternity wing|a candidate from the liberal wing of the party|some sportsmen make no scruple about firing into the thick of a wing of plover|George satisfied his keen urge to fly by winging homewards with the Royal Air Force|the prize will be winging its way to you soon|just jot down the title on a postcard and wing it to us|the convent was at some distance, but fear would wing her steps|one bird was winged for every bird killed|a little preparation puts you ahead of the job-seekers who try to wing it|

--Word--|Scott, Winfield |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1786–1866), US army officer; known as Old Fuss and Feathers. A hero of the War of 1812, he became supreme commander of the US Army 1841–61. During the Mexican War, he waged a victorious campaign from Veracruz to Mexico City in 1847. He ran for the office of US president as the Whig candidate in 1852 but was defeated by Democrat Franklin Pierce.|--Examples--|
--Word--|wing |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|(in a bird) a modified forelimb that bears large feathers and is used for flying.|(in a bat or pterosaur) a modified forelimb with skin stretched between or behind the fingers.|(in most insects) each of two or four flat extensions of the thoracic cuticle, either transparent or covered in scales.|The wing of a bird as food.|Used with reference to ease and swiftness of movement.|A rigid horizontal structure that projects from both sides of an aircraft and supports it in the air.|A pilot's certificate of ability to fly a plane, indicated by a badge representing a pair of wings.|A raised part of the body of a car or other vehicle above the wheel.|A part of a large building, especially one that projects from the main part.|A group within a political party or other organization having particular views or a particular function.|The sides of a theatre stage out of view of the audience.|(in soccer, rugby, and hockey) the part of the field close to the sidelines.|An attacking player positioned near to one of the sidelines.|A lateral part or projection of an organ or structure.|A thin membranous appendage of a fruit or seed that is dispersed by the wind.|An air force unit of several squadrons or groups.|The right or left flank of the main body of a battle formation.|A flock of plovers (birds)|Travel on wings or by aircraft; fly.|Move, travel, or be sent quickly, as if flying.|Send or convey (something) quickly, as if by air.|Enable (someone or something) to fly or move rapidly.|Shoot (a bird) in the wing, so as to prevent flight without causing death.|Wound (someone) superficially, especially in the arm or shoulder.|Speak or act without preparation; improvise.|--Examples--|the thought gave wings to her feet|Michael earned his wings as a commercial pilot|a maternity wing|a candidate from the liberal wing of the party|some sportsmen make no scruple about firing into the thick of a wing of plover|George satisfied his keen urge to fly by winging homewards with the Royal Air Force|the prize will be winging its way to you soon|just jot down the title on a postcard and wing it to us|the convent was at some distance, but fear would wing her steps|one bird was winged for every bird killed|a little preparation puts you ahead of the job-seekers who try to wing it|

--Word--|Winnipeg |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|The capital of Manitoba, situated in the south of the province at the confluence of the Assiniboine and Red Rivers, to the south of Lake Winnipeg; population 633,451 (2006). First settled as a French trading post in 1738, it became a trading post of the Hudson's Bay Company in 1821. It grew rapidly after the arrival of the railway in 1881.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Winthrop, John |--Type--|proper noun, proper noun|--Meanings--|(1588–1649), American colonial leader, born in England. He was the first governor 1630–49 of the Massachusetts Bay Colony. His son John Winthrop, Jr. (1606–76), also born in England, served as the governor of Connecticut 1657, 1659–76.|(1714–79), American astronomer and physicist. He was the first American to practice rigorous experimental science, giving laboratory demonstrations of electricity in 1746 and predicting the return of Halley's Comet in 1759.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Wisconsin |--Type--|proper noun, noun|--Meanings--|A state in the northern US, bordering on Lakes Superior (in the north-west) and Michigan (in the east); population 5,627,967 (est. 2008); capital, Madison. Ceded to Britain by the French in 1763 and acquired by the US in 1783 as part of the former Northwest Territory, it became the 30th state of the US in 1848.|The last (or last two) of the Pleistocene glaciations of North America, approximating to the Weichsel of northern Europe.|The system of deposits laid down at the time of the Wisconsin glaciation.|--Examples--|

--Word--|wishbone |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A forked bone (the furcula) between the neck and breast of a bird. According to a popular custom, this bone from a cooked bird is broken by two people and the holder of the longer portion is then entitled to make a wish.|A forked element in the suspension of a motor vehicle or aircraft, typically attached to a wheel at one end with the two arms hinged to the chassis.|A boom in two halves which curve outwards around a sail and meet aft of it.|--Examples--|double wishbone suspension|

--Word--|witchweed |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A small parasitic plant which attaches itself to the roots of other plants. Native to the Old World tropics and southern Africa, it can cause serious damage to crops such as maize and sugar.|--Examples--|

--Word--|withdraw |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Remove or take away (something) from a particular place or position.|Take (money) out of an account.|Discontinue or no longer provide (something previously supplied or offered)|Say that (a statement one has made) is untrue or unjustified.|(of a man) practise coitus interruptus.|Leave or cause to leave a place or situation.|Cease to participate in an activity or be a member of a team or organization.|Prevent (someone) from participating in an activity.|Depart to another place in search of quiet or privacy.|Cease to take an addictive drug.|--Examples--|Ruth withdrew her hand from his|she prised open the lid and withdrew a slim diamond ring|normally you can withdraw up to £50 in cash|the party threatened to withdraw its support for the government|he failed to withdraw his remarks and apologize|it put me off taking the Pill—my partner now withdraws|UN forces withdrew from the province|both countries agreed to withdraw their troops|his rival withdrew from the race on the second lap|patients were withdrawn from therapy when they had been depression-free for a month|they withdrew to their rooms for a siesta|he went silent and withdrew into himself|for the cocaine user, it is possible to withdraw without medication|

--Word--|witness |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A person who sees an event, typically a crime or accident, take place.|A person giving sworn testimony to a court of law or the police.|A person who is present at the signing of a document and signs it themselves to confirm this.|Evidence; proof.|Used to refer to confirmation or evidence given by signature or under oath.|Open profession of one's religious faith through words or actions.|A line or remnant of an original surface on a workpiece to show how much material has been removed or the shape of the original outline.|See (an event, typically a crime or accident) happen.|Be present as someone signs (a document) or gives (their signature) to a document and sign it oneself to confirm this.|Have knowledge of (a development) from observation or experience.|Be the place, period, or setting in which (an event or development) takes place.|Be a sign or proof of (something); serve as evidence.|Used to introduce an example that proves a preceding statement.|Openly profess one's religious faith.|--Examples--|police are appealing for witnesses to the accident|I was witness to one of the most amazing comebacks in sprinting history|a key witness at the trial|oral evidence set down in witness statements|a deed signed in the presence of a witness|the memorial service was witness to the wide circle of his interests|in witness thereof, the parties sign this document|they will be able to give witness of their faith and confidence in God|staff who witnessed the murder|the clerk witnessed her signature|what we are witnessing is the birth of a new political entity|the 1980s witnessed an unprecedented increase in the scope of the electronic media|the mid-1980s saw an intensification of interest in community care, as witnessed by the publication of four major reports|his writings witness to an inner toughness|the nuclear family is a vulnerable institution—witness the rates of marital breakdown|one of the purposes of his coming was to nerve the disciples to witness to Jesus|

--Word--|Witwatersrand |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|A region of South Africa, around the city of Johannesburg. Consisting of a series of parallel rocky ridges, it forms a watershed between the Vaal and Olifant Rivers. The region contains rich gold deposits, first discovered in 1886. Also called the Rand.|--Examples--|

--Word--|woad |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A yellow-flowered European plant of the cabbage family. It was formerly widely grown in Britain as a source of blue dye, which was extracted from the leaves after they had been dried, powdered, and fermented.|Dye obtained from the woad plant, now superseded by synthetic products.|--Examples--|
--Word--|woaded |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Of cloth or wool: dyed or coloured with woad (now chiefly historical). Of a person or human body: painted or adorned with blue body paint or dye made from woad; compare woad (now rare).|Designating a colour, especially black, that results from dyeing cloth or wool that has previously been dyed with woad; compare woading. Also: designating a dye which has a basis of woad or is made from woad. Now chiefly historical.|--Examples--|
--Word--|woader |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|(A) A cultivator of woad. (b) A person engaged in dyeing with woad.|--Examples--|
--Word--|woady |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Painted or smeared with woad.|--Examples--|
--Word--|woad-leaved |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having leaves resembling those of a woad plant in appearance (chiefly in the names of particular plants).|--Examples--|
--Word--|woadman |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A person (especially a man) who grows or cultivates woad or prepares it for use as a dye.|--Examples--|
--Word--|woad |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A yellow-flowered European plant of the cabbage family. It was formerly widely grown in Britain as a source of blue dye, which was extracted from the leaves after they had been dried, powdered, and fermented.|Dye obtained from the woad plant, now superseded by synthetic products.|--Examples--|
--Word--|woading |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of dyeing cloth, wool, etc., with woad, especially prior to dyeing with other colours or dyes. Now rare.|The action of planting and growing a crop of woad; the cultivation of woad; compare woad. Now historical and rare.|--Examples--|

--Word--|wolf |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A wild carnivorous mammal which is the largest member of the dog family, living and hunting in packs. It is native to both Eurasia and North America, but is much persecuted and has been widely exterminated.|Used in names of mammals similar or related to the wolf, e.g. maned wolf, Tasmanian wolf.|Used figuratively to refer to a rapacious, ferocious, or voracious person or thing.|A man who habitually seduces women.|A homosexual who habitually seduces men or adopts an active role with a partner.|A harsh or out-of-tune effect produced when playing particular notes or intervals on a musical instrument, caused either by the instrument's construction or by divergence from equal temperament.|Devour (food) greedily.|--Examples--|he calls the media ravening wolves|he's the archetypal wolf in Armani threads|he wolfed down his breakfast|

--Word--|Tone, Wolfe |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1763–98), Irish nationalist; full name Theobald Wolfe Tone. In 1794 he induced a French invasion of Ireland to overthrow English rule, which failed. Tone was captured by the British during the Irish insurrection in 1798 and committed suicide in prison.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Pauli, Wolfgang |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1900–58), Austrian-born American physicist. He made a major contribution to quantum theory with the Pauli exclusion principle. In 1931 he postulated the existence of the neutrino, later discovered by Enrico Fermi. Nobel Prize for Physics (1945).|--Examples--|

Wollaston also demonstrated that static and current electricity were the same and was the first to observe the dark lines in the solar spectrum.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Wolsey, Thomas |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(c.1474–1530), English churchman and statesman; known as Cardinal Wolsey. Wolsey dominated foreign and domestic policy in the early part of Henry VIII's reign, but incurred royal displeasure through his failure to secure the papal dispensation necessary for Henry's divorce from Catherine of Aragon. He was arrested on a charge of treason and died on his way to trial.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Woodstock |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|A small town in New York State, situated in the south-east near Albany. --Word--|Woodward, Robert |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(born 1943), US journalist; full name Robert Upshur Woodward. He was the Washington Post reporter who, with Carl Bernstein, broke the story of the Watergate burglary and traced the financial payoffs to President Nixon. With Bernstein, he wrote All the President's Men (1974) and The Final Days (1976). He is also the author of The Choice (1996), Shadow: Five Presidents and the Legacy of Watergate (1999), and Plan of Attack (2004).|--Examples--|

--Word--|Woolf, Virginia |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1882–1941), English novelist, essayist, and critic; born Adeline Virginia Stephen. A member of the Bloomsbury Group, she gained recognition with Jacob's Room (1922). Subsequent novels, such as Mrs Dalloway (1925) and To the Lighthouse (1927), characterized by their poetic impressionism, established her as an exponent of modernism.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Woolsack |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|(in the UK) the Lord Chancellor's wool-stuffed seat in the House of Lords. It is said to have been adopted in Edward III's reign as a reminder to the Lords of the importance to England of the wool trade.|The position of Lord Chancellor.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Worcester |--Type--|proper noun, noun|--Meanings--|A cathedral city in western England, on the River Severn, the administrative centre of Worcestershire; population 96,300 (est. 2009). It was the scene in 1651, during the English Civil War, of a battle in which Oliver Cromwell defeated a Scottish army under Charles II. --Word--|word |--Type--|noun, verb, exclamation|--Meanings--|A single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing, used with others (or sometimes alone) to form a sentence and typically shown with a space on either side when written or printed.|A single distinct conceptual unit of language, comprising inflected and variant forms.|Something spoken or written; a remark or statement.|Even the smallest amount of something spoken or written.|Angry talk.|Speech as distinct from action.|A command, password, or signal.|Communication; news.|One's account of the truth, especially when it differs from that of another person.|A promise or assurance.|The text or spoken part of a play, opera, or other performed piece; a script.|A basic unit of data in a computer, typically 16 or 32 bits long.|Express (something spoken or written) in particular words.|Used to express agreement or affirmation.|--Examples--|I don't like the word unofficial|why so many words for so few ideas?|his grandfather's words had been meant kindly|a word of warning|don't believe a word of it|her father would have had words with her about that|he conforms in word and deed to the values of a society that he rejects|someone gave me the word to start playing|I was afraid to leave Edinburgh in case there was word from the War Office|in court it would have been his word against mine|everything will be taken care of—you have my word|he had to learn his words|he words his request in a particularly ironic way|a strongly worded letter of protest|Word, that's a good record, man|

--Word--|beat |--Type--|verb, noun, adjective|--Meanings--|Strike (a person or an animal) repeatedly and violently so as to hurt or injure them, typically with an implement such as a club or whip.|Strike (an object) repeatedly so as to make a noise.|(of an instrument) make a rhythmical sound through being struck.|Strike (a carpet, blanket, etc.) repeatedly in order to remove dust.|Flatten or shape (metal) by striking it repeatedly with a hammer.|Strike something against (something)|Strike repeatedly at or on something.|Move across (an area of land) repeatedly striking at the ground cover in order to raise game birds for shooting.|Defeat (someone) in a game or other competitive situation.|Overcome (a problem or disease)|Do or be better than (a record or score)|Be better than.|Baffle.|Succeed in getting somewhere ahead of (someone)|Take action to avoid (difficulty or inconvenience)|(of the heart) pulsate.|(of a bird) move (the wings) up and down.|(of a bird) fly making rhythmic wing movements.|Stir (cooking ingredients) vigorously to make a smooth or frothy mixture.|Leave.|Sail into the wind, following a zigzag course with repeated tacking.|A main accent or rhythmic unit in music or poetry.|A strong rhythm in popular music.|A regular, rhythmic sound or movement.|The sound made when something, especially a musical instrument, is struck.|A pulsation of the heart.|A periodic variation of sound or amplitude due to the combination of two sounds, electrical signals, or other vibrations having similar but not identical frequencies.|The movement of a bird's wings.|An area allocated to a police officer and patrolled on foot.|A spell of duty allocated to a police officer.|An area regularly frequented by someone.|A person's area of interest.|A stretch of water fished by an angler.|A brief pause or moment of hesitation.|Completely exhausted.|Relating to the beat generation or its philosophy.|--Examples--|if we were caught we were beaten|the victims were beaten to death with baseball bats|they beat me with a stick and punched me|he beat the table with his hand|drums were beating in the distance|upright cleaners have a motorized head which beats the carpet to loosen the dirt|pure gold can be beaten out to form very thin sheets|she beat her fists against the wood|Sidney beat on the door with the flat of his hand|Emmie began to beat at the flames|they hire boys to beat the Yorkshire moors for game birds|she beat him easily at chess|Juventus were beaten 2–1|the battle to beat car crime|he beat heroin addiction in 1992|he beat his own world record|you can't beat the taste of fresh raspberries|it beats me how you manage to work in this heat|the defender beat him to the ball|they set off early to beat the traffic|her heart beat faster with panic|doves wheel around the rooftops, beating their wings|an owl beat low over the salt marsh|beat the butter until light and fluffy|beat the cream into the mixture|now beat it, will you!|we beat southwards all that first day|the glissando begins on the second beat|the music changed to a funky disco beat|the beat of the wipers became almost hypnotic|he heard a regular drum beat|the beat of the swallow's wings as they dive after midges|his beat was in North London|it's important to have cops on the beat|his beat ended at 6 a.m|a few, new to their beat, looked at him with interest|his beat is construction, property, and hotels|you don't necessarily have to fish on the priciest beats to find good sport|she waited for a beat of three seconds|I'm beat—I need an hour or so to rest|beat poet Allen Ginsberg|

--Word--|word |--Type--|noun, verb, exclamation|--Meanings--|A single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing, used with others (or sometimes alone) to form a sentence and typically shown with a space on either side when written or printed.|A single distinct conceptual unit of language, comprising inflected and variant forms.|Something spoken or written; a remark or statement.|Even the smallest amount of something spoken or written.|Angry talk.|Speech as distinct from action.|A command, password, or signal.|Communication; news.|One's account of the truth, especially when it differs from that of another person.|A promise or assurance.|The text or spoken part of a play, opera, or other performed piece; a script.|A basic unit of data in a computer, typically 16 or 32 bits long.|Express (something spoken or written) in particular words.|Used to express agreement or affirmation.|--Examples--|I don't like the word unofficial|why so many words for so few ideas?|his grandfather's words had been meant kindly|a word of warning|don't believe a word of it|her father would have had words with her about that|he conforms in word and deed to the values of a society that he rejects|someone gave me the word to start playing|I was afraid to leave Edinburgh in case there was word from the War Office|in court it would have been his word against mine|everything will be taken care of—you have my word|he had to learn his words|he words his request in a particularly ironic way|a strongly worded letter of protest|Word, that's a good record, man|

--Word--|word |--Type--|noun, verb, exclamation|--Meanings--|A single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing, used with others (or sometimes alone) to form a sentence and typically shown with a space on either side when written or printed.|A single distinct conceptual unit of language, comprising inflected and variant forms.|Something spoken or written; a remark or statement.|Even the smallest amount of something spoken or written.|Angry talk.|Speech as distinct from action.|A command, password, or signal.|Communication; news.|One's account of the truth, especially when it differs from that of another person.|A promise or assurance.|The text or spoken part of a play, opera, or other performed piece; a script.|A basic unit of data in a computer, typically 16 or 32 bits long.|Express (something spoken or written) in particular words.|Used to express agreement or affirmation.|--Examples--|I don't like the word unofficial|why so many words for so few ideas?|his grandfather's words had been meant kindly|a word of warning|don't believe a word of it|her father would have had words with her about that|he conforms in word and deed to the values of a society that he rejects|someone gave me the word to start playing|I was afraid to leave Edinburgh in case there was word from the War Office|in court it would have been his word against mine|everything will be taken care of—you have my word|he had to learn his words|he words his request in a particularly ironic way|a strongly worded letter of protest|Word, that's a good record, man|

--Word--|Wordsworth, William |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1770–1850), English poet. Much of his work was inspired by the Lake District. His Lyrical Ballads (1798), which was composed with Coleridge and included Tintern Abbey, was a landmark in romanticism. Other notable poems: I Wandered Lonely as a Cloud (sonnet, 1815) and The Prelude (1850). He was appointed Poet Laureate in 1843.|--Examples--|
--Word--|Wordsworthian |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Relating to or characteristic of the English poet William Wordsworth or his works.|A student or admirer of the English poet William Wordsworth or his works.|--Examples--|this form of Wordsworthian reverence for nature was immensely influential in American life|even Wordsworthians are cautious in commenting on the poem|

--Word--|work |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|Activity involving mental or physical effort done in order to achieve a purpose or result.|Mental or physical activity as a means of earning income; employment.|The place where one is employed.|The period of time one spends in paid employment.|A job.|A task or tasks to be undertaken.|The materials for a task.|Activity involving construction or repair.|Cosmetic plastic surgery.|Good or moral deeds.|A thing or things done or made; the result of an action.|A literary or musical composition or other piece of art.|The artistic production of a particular author, composer, or artist, regarded collectively.|A piece of embroidery, sewing, or knitting, typically made using a specified stitch or method.|A place or premises in which industrial or manufacturing processes are carried out.|The operative part of a clock or other machine.|A defensive structure.|The exertion of force overcoming resistance or producing molecular change.|Everything needed, desired, or expected.|Be engaged in physical or mental activity in order to achieve a result; do work.|Be employed in a specified occupation or field.|Set to or keep at work.|Practise one's occupation in or at (a particular place)|Be engaged in (a particular occupation)|(of a machine or system) function, especially properly or effectively.|(with reference to a machine or machine part) be or cause to be in operation.|(of a plan or method) have the desired result or effect.|Produce as a result.|Make efforts to achieve something; campaign.|Arrange or contrive.|Exert influence or persuasion on.|Use one's persuasive power to stir the emotions of.|Bring (a material or mixture) to a desired shape or consistency by hammering, kneading, etc.|Produce artistic pieces using (a particular material or medium)|Produce (an article or design) using a specified material or sewing stitch.|Cultivate (land) or extract materials from (a mine or quarry)|Move or cause to move gradually or with difficulty into another position.|(of a person's features) move violently or convulsively.|Make progress to windward, with repeated tacking.|Bring into a specified emotional state.|--Examples--|he was tired after a day's work in the fields|I'm still looking for work|I was returning home from work on a packed subway|he was going to the theatre after work|I decided to get a work|they made sure the work was progressing smoothly|she frequently took work home with her|extra costs caused by additional building works|between you and me, I think he's had some work done|the Clapham sect was concerned with works rather than with faith|her work hangs in all the main American collections|the bombing had been the work of a German-based cell|a work of fiction|the works of Schubert fill several feet of shelf space|he found a job in the locomotive works|she could almost hear the tick of its works|just north of the fort were trenches and the freshly reconstructed patriot siege works|the heavens put on a show: sheet lightning, hailstones, the works|an engineer who was working on a design for a more efficient wing|new contracts forcing employees to work longer hours|he worked as a waiter in a rather shabby restaurant|Jane is working you too hard|I worked a few clubs and so forth|I worked fireman on ships|his phone doesn't work unless he goes to a high point|the device is designed to go into a special rest state when it's not working|teaching customers how to work a VCR|the desperate ploy had worked|with a dash of blusher here and there, you can work miracles|they are dedicated to working for a better future for the generations to come|the chairman was prepared to work it for Phillip if he was interested|she worked upon the sympathy of her associates|the born politician's art of working a crowd|work the mixture into a paste with your hands|he works in clay over a very strong frame|the castle itself is worked in tent stitch|contracts and leases to work the mines|comb hair from tip to root, working out the knots at the end|look for small parts that might work loose|hair wild, mouth working furiously|trying to work to windward in light airs|Harold had worked himself into a minor rage|

--Word--|worker |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A person who does a specified type of work or who works in a specified way.|An employee, especially one who does manual or non-executive work.|A person who works hard.|Used in Marxist or leftist contexts to refer to the working class.|A person who achieves a specified thing.|A neuter or undeveloped female bee, wasp, ant, or other social insect, large numbers of which do the basic work of the colony.|--Examples--|a farm worker|she's a good worker|I got a reputation for being a worker|a red flag with the inscription workers of the world, unite!|the Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party|he was a bogus worker of miracles|

--Word--|priest-worker |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|(Originally and chiefly with reference to France) a Roman Catholic priest who earns his living by doing manual or industrial work, especially during the period after the Second World War (now chiefly historical); (also more widely) any priest engaged, typically part-time, in secular work.|--Examples--|

--Word--|workie |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|US. Usually with capital initial. A member or supporter of the Working Men's Party, a short-lived political party of the early 19th cent. which advocated the interests of the working class. Chiefly in plural Now historical.|More generally: a worker, especially a manual labourer. Frequently Scottish in later use.|--Examples--|
--Word--|working |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Having paid employment.|Engaged in manual labour.|Relating to, suitable for, or for the purpose of work.|(of an animal) used in farming, hunting, or for guard duties; not kept as a pet or for show.|Functioning or able to function.|(of parts of a machine) moving and causing a machine to operate.|(of a theory, definition, or title) used as the basis for work or argument and likely to be developed or improved later.|Sufficient to work with at a basic level.|The action of doing work.|A scheduled duty or trip performed by a locomotive, train, bus, or other vehicle.|The way in which a machine, organization, or system operates.|The record of the successive calculations made in solving a mathematical problem.|A mine or a part of a mine from which minerals are being extracted.|--Examples--|the size of the working population|the vote is no longer sufficient protection for the working man|improvements in living and working conditions|the Norfolk Terrier was developed as a working dog on farms|the mill still has a working waterwheel|the working parts of a digital watch|his working title for the book was Why People Are Poor|they have a working knowledge of contract law|working with animals teaches patience|locomotive 37418 is often seen on this working|we will be less secretive about the workings of government|show details of workings in your answer book|a modern mine on the site of old workings|

--Word--|work |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|Activity involving mental or physical effort done in order to achieve a purpose or result.|Mental or physical activity as a means of earning income; employment.|The place where one is employed.|The period of time one spends in paid employment.|A job.|A task or tasks to be undertaken.|The materials for a task.|Activity involving construction or repair.|Cosmetic plastic surgery.|Good or moral deeds.|A thing or things done or made; the result of an action.|A literary or musical composition or other piece of art.|The artistic production of a particular author, composer, or artist, regarded collectively.|A piece of embroidery, sewing, or knitting, typically made using a specified stitch or method.|A place or premises in which industrial or manufacturing processes are carried out.|The operative part of a clock or other machine.|A defensive structure.|The exertion of force overcoming resistance or producing molecular change.|Everything needed, desired, or expected.|Be engaged in physical or mental activity in order to achieve a result; do work.|Be employed in a specified occupation or field.|Set to or keep at work.|Practise one's occupation in or at (a particular place)|Be engaged in (a particular occupation)|(of a machine or system) function, especially properly or effectively.|(with reference to a machine or machine part) be or cause to be in operation.|(of a plan or method) have the desired result or effect.|Produce as a result.|Make efforts to achieve something; campaign.|Arrange or contrive.|Exert influence or persuasion on.|Use one's persuasive power to stir the emotions of.|Bring (a material or mixture) to a desired shape or consistency by hammering, kneading, etc.|Produce artistic pieces using (a particular material or medium)|Produce (an article or design) using a specified material or sewing stitch.|Cultivate (land) or extract materials from (a mine or quarry)|Move or cause to move gradually or with difficulty into another position.|(of a person's features) move violently or convulsively.|Make progress to windward, with repeated tacking.|Bring into a specified emotional state.|--Examples--|he was tired after a day's work in the fields|I'm still looking for work|I was returning home from work on a packed subway|he was going to the theatre after work|I decided to get a work|they made sure the work was progressing smoothly|she frequently took work home with her|extra costs caused by additional building works|between you and me, I think he's had some work done|the Clapham sect was concerned with works rather than with faith|her work hangs in all the main American collections|the bombing had been the work of a German-based cell|a work of fiction|the works of Schubert fill several feet of shelf space|he found a job in the locomotive works|she could almost hear the tick of its works|just north of the fort were trenches and the freshly reconstructed patriot siege works|the heavens put on a show: sheet lightning, hailstones, the works|an engineer who was working on a design for a more efficient wing|new contracts forcing employees to work longer hours|he worked as a waiter in a rather shabby restaurant|Jane is working you too hard|I worked a few clubs and so forth|I worked fireman on ships|his phone doesn't work unless he goes to a high point|the device is designed to go into a special rest state when it's not working|teaching customers how to work a VCR|the desperate ploy had worked|with a dash of blusher here and there, you can work miracles|they are dedicated to working for a better future for the generations to come|the chairman was prepared to work it for Phillip if he was interested|she worked upon the sympathy of her associates|the born politician's art of working a crowd|work the mixture into a paste with your hands|he works in clay over a very strong frame|the castle itself is worked in tent stitch|contracts and leases to work the mines|comb hair from tip to root, working out the knots at the end|look for small parts that might work loose|hair wild, mouth working furiously|trying to work to windward in light --Word--|choke |--Type--|verb, noun, noun|--Meanings--|(of a person or animal) have severe difficulty in breathing because of a constricted or obstructed throat or a lack of air.|Cause (a person or animal) to choke.|Swallow something with difficulty.|Prevent (a plant) from growing by depriving it of light, air, or nourishment.|Prevent or inhibit the occurrence or development of.|(in sports) fail to perform at a crucial point of a game or contest as a result of nervousness.|Fill (a space) so as to make movement difficult or impossible.|Make (someone) speechless with a strong feeling or emotion.|Cause (someone) to feel tearful or extremely upset.|Suppress a strong emotion or the expression of such an emotion.|Enrich the fuel mixture in (a petrol engine) by reducing the intake of air.|A valve in the carburettor of a petrol engine that is used to reduce the amount of air in the fuel mixture when the engine is started.|A knob which controls the choke in a carburettor.|A narrowed part of a shotgun bore near the muzzle, serving to restrict the spread of the shot.|An inductance coil used to smooth the variations of an alternating current or to alter its phase.|An act or the sound of a person or animal having difficulty in breathing.|The inedible mass of silky fibres at the centre of a globe artichoke.|--Examples--|Willie choked on a mouthful of tea|the toys contained parts that could choke a very young child|I attempted to choke down supper|the bracken will choke the wild gladiolus|higher rates of interest choke off investment demand|we were the only team not to choke when it came to the crunch|the roads were choked with traffic|he was choked with fury|I was so choked up I started crying and couldn't sing any more|I just choked up reading it|Liz was choking back her anger|carbon monoxide results during a cold start, when an engine is choked|an automatic choke|too much choke does not help|he pulled the choke out to its full extent|many guns may not have the right choke|a full choke gun|a little choke of laughter|

--Word--|read |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Look at and comprehend the meaning of (written or printed matter) by interpreting the characters or symbols of which it is composed.|Have the ability to look at and comprehend the meaning of written or printed matter.|Speak (the written or printed matter that one is reading) aloud.|Habitually read (a particular newspaper or periodical)|(of a passage, text, or sign) have a certain wording.|Used to indicate that a particular word in a text or passage is incorrect and that another should be substituted for it.|(of an actor) audition for (a role)|Discover (information) by reading it in a written or printed source.|Having a specified level of knowledge as a result of reading.|Discern (a fact, emotion, or quality) in someone's eyes or expression.|Understand or interpret the nature or significance of.|(of a piece of writing) convey a specified impression to the reader.|Inspect and record the figure indicated on (a measuring instrument)|(of a measuring instrument) indicate a specified measurement or figure.|Study (an academic subject) at a university.|(of a computer) copy, transfer, or interpret (data)|Enter or extract (data) in an electronic storage device.|(of a device) obtain data from (light or other input)|Present (a bill or other measure) before a legislative assembly.|Hear and understand the words of (someone speaking on a radio transmitter)|A period or act of reading something.|A book considered in terms of its readability.|A person's interpretation of something.|--Examples--|it's the best novel I've ever read|I never learned to read music|Emily read over her notes|I'll go to bed and read for a while|only three of the girls could read and none could write|I read the letter to her|the charges against him were read out|I'll read to you if you like|now, I know what my reputation is—I read the papers|the placard read We want justice|for madam read madman|ring your agent and say you'll read for the part|he was arrested yesterday—I read it in the paper|I read about the course in a magazine|Ada was well read in French literature|he is a man deeply read in history, philosophy, and theology|she looked down, terrified that he would read fear on her face|he didn't dare look away, in case this was read as a sign of weakness|the brief note read like a cry for help|I've come to read the gas meter|the thermometer read 0° C|I'm reading English at Cambridge|he went to Manchester to read for a BA in Economics|it attempts to read a floppy disk without regard to its format|the commonest way of reading a file into the system|the microchip gives a unique code when read by the scanner|the bill was accordingly read a second time|Do you read me? Over.|I was having a quiet read of the newspaper|the book is a thoroughly entertaining read|their read on the national situation may be correct|

--Word--|spread |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Open out (something) so as to extend its surface area, width, or length.|Stretch out (arms, legs, hands, fingers, or wings) so that they are far apart.|Extend over a large or increasing area.|(of a group of people) move apart so as to cover a wider area.|Distribute or disperse (something) over an area.|Gradually reach or cause to reach a wider area or more people.|(of people, animals, or plants) become distributed over a large or larger area.|Distribute in a specified way.|Apply (a substance) to an object or surface in an even layer.|Cover (a surface) with a substance in an even layer.|Be able to be applied in an even layer.|Lay (a table) for a meal.|The fact or process of spreading over an area.|The extent, width, or area covered by something.|The wingspan of a bird.|An expanse or amount of something.|A large farm or ranch.|The range or variety of something.|The difference between two rates or prices.|A soft paste that can be applied in a layer to bread or other food.|An article or advertisement covering several columns or pages of a newspaper or magazine, especially one on two facing pages.|A large and impressively elaborate meal.|A bedspread.|--Examples--|I spread a towel on the sand and sat down|she helped Colin to spread out the map|Bobby spread his arms wide|rain over north-west Scotland will spread south-east during the day|the Marines spread out across the docks|volcanic eruptions spread dust high into the stratosphere|the violence spread from the city centre to the suburbs|she's always spreading rumours|the owls have spread as far north as Kuala Lumpur|you can spread the payments over as long a period as you like|he sighed, spreading jam on a croissant|spread each slice thinly with mayonnaise|a tub of unsalted butter that spreads so well|warmer temperatures could help reduce the spread of the disease|the spread of the urban population into rural areas|the male's antlers can attain a spread of six feet|the red-tailed hawk has a four-and-a-half-foot spread|the green spread of the park|a wide spread of ages|the very narrow spread between borrowing and deposit rates|low-fat spreads|cheese spread|a double-page spread|his mother laid on a huge spread|a patchwork spread|

--Word--|worm |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|Any of a number of creeping or burrowing invertebrate animals with long, slender soft bodies and no limbs.|Intestinal or other internal parasites.|Used in names of long slender insect larvae, especially those in fruit or wood, e.g. army worm, woodworm.|Used in names of other animals that resemble worms in some way, e.g. slow-worm, shipworm.|A maggot regarded as eating corpses buried in the ground.|A weak or despicable person (often used as a general term of abuse)|A helical device or component.|The threaded cylinder in a worm gear.|The coiled pipe of a still in which the vapour is cooled and condensed.|A self-replicating program able to propagate itself across a network, typically having a detrimental effect.|Move with difficulty by crawling or wriggling.|Move (something) into a confined space by wriggling it.|Insinuate one's way into.|Obtain information from (someone) by cunning persistence.|Treat (an animal) with a preparation designed to expel parasitic worms.|Make (a rope) smooth by winding thread between the strands.|--Examples--|she ate so much so often that I thought she had worms|food for worms|it was unbearable that such a worm could be so successful|you ungrateful little worm!|I wormed my way along the roadside ditch|I wormed my right hand between my body and the earth|you wormed your way into their lives|I did manage to worm a few details out of him|I wormed her over a course of three weeks|

--Word--|worry |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Feel or cause to feel anxious or troubled about actual or potential problems.|Discover or solve something by persistent thought.|Annoy or disturb.|(of a dog or other carnivorous animal) tear at or pull about with the teeth.|(of a dog) chase and attack (livestock, especially sheep)|Pull at or fiddle with repeatedly.|The state of being anxious and troubled over actual or potential problems.|A source of anxiety.|--Examples--|he worried about his soldier sons in the war|I began to worry whether I had done the right thing|there was no need to worry her|children should be allowed to pause in their reading to worry out a meaning|the noise never really stops, but it doesn't worry me|I found my dog contentedly worrying a bone|a farmer shot a dog that had been worrying sheep|he began to worry at the knot in the cord|Mam says she's demented with worry|he's got financial worries|

--Word--|worry |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Feel or cause to feel anxious or troubled about actual or potential problems.|Discover or solve something by persistent thought.|Annoy or disturb.|(of a dog or other carnivorous animal) tear at or pull about with the teeth.|(of a dog) chase and attack (livestock, especially sheep)|Pull at or fiddle with repeatedly.|The state of being anxious and troubled over actual or potential problems.|A source of anxiety.|--Examples--|he worried about his soldier sons in the war|I began to worry whether I had done the right thing|there was no need to worry her|children should be allowed to pause in their reading to worry out a meaning|the noise never really stops, but it doesn't worry me|I found my dog contentedly worrying a bone|a farmer shot a dog that had been worrying sheep|he began to worry at the knot in the cord|Mam says she's demented with worry|he's got financial worries|
--Word--|worrying |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Causing anxiety about actual or potential problems; alarming.|--Examples--|a worrying health risk|
--Word--|worryingly |--Type--|adverb|--Meanings--|In a way that causes anxiety about actual or potential problems.|--Examples--|the wind howled and my tin roof rattled worryingly|his words now sound worryingly prophetic|worryingly, the plan has been discarded|

--Word--|worrisomely |--Type--|adverb|--Meanings--|--Examples--|he sits on a worrisomely flimsy plastic chair|

--Word--|worse |--Type--|adjective, adverb, noun|--Meanings--|Of poorer quality or lower standard; less good or desirable.|More serious or severe.|More reprehensible or evil.|More ill or unhappy.|Less well or skilfully.|More seriously or severely.|A more serious or unpleasant event or situation.|A less good, favourable, or pleasant condition.|--Examples--|the accommodation was awful and the food was worse|I'm becoming a worse footballer every week|the movement made the pain worse|it is worse to intend harm than to be indifferent|he felt worse, and groped his way back to bed|the more famous I became the worse I painted|the others had been drunk too, worse than herself|the small department was already stretched to the limit, but worse was to follow|the weather changed for the worse|
--Word--|affected |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Influenced or touched by an external factor.|Artificial, pretentious, and designed to impress.|Disposed or inclined in a specified way.|--Examples--|affected areas|the gesture appeared both affected and stagy|you might become differently affected towards him|
--Word--|applied |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|(of a subject of study) put to practical use as opposed to being theoretical.|--Examples--|applied chemistry|
--Word--|bodied |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having a body or trunk, typically of a specified kind.|Of wine, having the specified quality of flavour.|--Examples--|we are bodied beings|crayfish are heavy bodied crustaceans|the narrow bodied hangar|a medium bodied Cabernet|

--Word--|worship |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|The feeling or expression of reverence and adoration for a deity.|Religious rites or ceremonies, constituting a formal expression of reverence for a deity.|Great admiration or devotion shown towards a person or principle.|Honour given to someone in recognition of their merit.|Used in addressing or referring to an important or high-ranking person, especially a magistrate or mayor.|Show reverence and adoration for (a deity)|Take part in a religious ceremony.|Feel great admiration or devotion for.|--Examples--|worship of the Mother Goddess|ancestor worship|the church was opened for public worship|the worship of celebrity and wealth|we were soon joined by His Worship the Mayor|the Maya built jungle pyramids to worship their gods|the family worshipped at Trinity Church|she adores her sons and they worship her|
--Word--|worshipper |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A person who shows reverence and adoration for a deity.|A person who feels great admiration or devotion for someone or something.|--Examples--|Viking warriors, worshippers of Thor and Odin|three thousand worshippers attend the mosque|Edward was an unrepentant worshipper of power|

--Word--|worst |--Type--|adjective, adverb, noun, verb|--Meanings--|Of the poorest quality or the lowest standard; least good or desirable.|Most severe or serious.|Most severely or seriously.|Least well or pleasingly.|The most serious or unpleasant thing that could happen.|The most serious or unpleasant part of something.|Get the better of; defeat.|--Examples--|he was the company's worst driver|the speech was the worst he had ever made|at least 32 people died in Australia's worst bus accident|manufacturing and mining are the industries worst affected by falling employment|he was voted the worst-dressed celebrity|when I saw the ambulance outside her front door, I began to fear the worst|there are signs that the recession is past its worst|this was not the time for a deep discussion—she was tired and she would be worsted|
--Word--|affected |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Influenced or touched by an external factor.|Artificial, pretentious, and designed to impress.|Disposed or inclined in a specified way.|--Examples--|affected areas|the gesture appeared both affected and stagy|you might become differently affected towards him|

--Word--|would |--Type--|modal verb|--Meanings--|(expressing the conditional mood) indicating the consequence of an imagined event or situation.|Used to give advice.|Expressing a desire or inclination.|Expressing a polite request.|Expressing willingness or consent.|Expressing a conjecture, opinion, or hope.|Used to make a comment about behaviour that is typical.|Expressing a wish or regret.|--Examples--|he said he would be away for a couple of days|she wouldn't leave|the windows would not close|he would lose his job if he were identified|I wouldn't drink that if I were you|I would love to work in America|would you like some water?|would you pour the wine, please?|who would live here?|I would imagine that they're home by now|I guess some people would consider it brutal|I would have to agree|they would say that, wouldn't they?|would that he had lived to finish it|

--Word--|wrap |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Cover or enclose in paper or soft material.|Arrange paper or soft material round (someone or something), typically as a covering or for warmth or protection.|Place an arm, finger, or leg round.|Clasp; embrace.|Crash a vehicle into (a stationary object)|Cause (a word or unit of text) to be carried over to a new line automatically as the margin is reached, or to fit around embedded features such as pictures.|(of a word or unit of text) be carried over automatically as the margin is reached.|Finish filming or recording.|A loose outer garment or piece of material.|(of a garment) having one part overlapping another; wrap-around.|Paper or soft material used for wrapping.|A veil of secrecy maintained about something, especially a new project.|A small packet of a powdered illegal drug.|The end of a session of filming or recording.|A tortilla wrapped around a cold filling, eaten as a sandwich.|wrap up|Put on (or dress someone in) warm clothes.|Be quiet; stop talking or making a noise.|be wrapped up in|Be so absorbed in (something) that one does not notice other people or things.|wrap something up|Complete or conclude a discussion or agreement.|Win a game or competition.|--Examples--|he wrapped up the Christmas presents|Leonora wrapped herself in a large white bath towel|wrap the bandage around the injured limb|he wrapped an arm around her waist|she wrapped him in her arms|Richard wrapped his car around a telegraph pole|the program can automatically wrap text around irregularly shaped graphics|words are wrapped to the next line if they are too long|when you type, the text wraps to the next line|the text in the document wraps around the image|we wrapped on schedule three days later|beach wraps|a wrap skirt|plastic food wrap|details of the police operation are being kept under wraps|a £5 wrap of speed|right, it's a wrap|wrap up warm|Tim was well wrapped up against the weather|he was too wrapped up in the historic importance of his campaign|they hope to wrap up negotiations within sixty days|Australia wrapped up the series 4–0|

--Word--|wreak |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Cause (a large amount of damage or harm)|Inflict (vengeance)|Avenge (someone who has been wronged)|--Examples--|torrential rainstorms wreaked havoc yesterday|the environmental damage wreaked by ninety years of phosphate mining|they would soon have a chance to wreak their revenge on the enemy|grant me some knight to wreak me for my son|
--Word--|wreath |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|An arrangement of flowers, leaves, or stems fastened in a ring and used for decoration or for laying on a grave.|A carved representation of a wreath.|A ring made of or resembling soft, twisted material.|A representation of a ring of twisted material below a crest (especially where it joins a helmet).|A curl or ring of smoke or cloud.|A snowdrift.|--Examples--|the Queen laid a wreath at the Cenotaph|a laurel wreath|a gold wreath|wreaths of mist swirled up into the cold air|

--Word--|wreck |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|The destruction of a ship at sea; a shipwreck.|A ship destroyed at sea.|Goods brought ashore by the sea from a wreck.|Something, especially a vehicle or building, that has been badly damaged or destroyed.|A road or rail crash.|A person whose physical or mental health or strength has failed.|Cause the destruction of (a ship) by sinking or breaking up.|Involve (someone) in a shipwreck.|Cause the destruction of a ship in order to steal the cargo.|Suffer or undergo shipwreck.|Destroy or severely damage (a structure, vehicle, or similar)|Spoil completely.|Engage in breaking up badly damaged vehicles or demolishing old buildings to obtain usable spares or scrap.|--Examples--|the survivors of the wreck|the salvaging of treasure from wrecks|the profits of wreck|the plane was reduced to a smouldering wreck|the wreck of their marriage|a train wreck|the scandal left the family emotional wrecks|he was drowned when his ship was wrecked|sailors who had the misfortune to be wrecked on these coasts|the locals reverted to the age-old practice of wrecking|my letters were in one of the vessels that wreck'd|the blast wrecked 100 houses|an eye injury wrecked his chances of a professional career|

--Word--|wrecker |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A person or thing that wrecks something.|A person who breaks up damaged vehicles or demolishes old buildings to obtain usable spares or scrap.|A recovery vehicle.|A person on the shore who tries to bring about a shipwreck in order to plunder or profit from the wreckage.|--Examples--|she was unfairly portrayed as a marriage wrecker|they raced out with the wrecker when they heard there'd been an accident|

--Word--|wrench |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A sudden violent twist or pull.|A feeling of sadness or distress caused by one's own or another's departure.|An adjustable tool like a spanner, used for gripping and turning nuts or bolts.|A combination of a couple with a force along its axis.|Pull or twist suddenly and violently.|Injure (a part of the body) as a result of a sudden twisting movement.|Distort to fit a particular theory or interpretation.|Turn (something, especially a nut or bolt) with a wrench.|--Examples--|with a wrench Tony wriggled free|it will be a real wrench to leave after eight years|you will need a wrench to tighten it in position|Casey grabbed the gun and wrenched it from my hand|she wrenched herself free of his grip|she slipped and wrenched her ankle|to wrench our Bible to make it fit a misconception of facts|

--Word--|wrestle |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Take part in a fight, either as sport or in earnest, that involves grappling with one's opponent and trying to throw or force them to the ground.|Force (someone) into a particular position or place by grappling with them.|Move or manipulate (something) with difficulty.|Struggle with a difficulty or problem.|A wrestling bout or contest.|A hard struggle.|--Examples--|as the policeman wrestled with the gunman a shot rang out|the security guards wrestled them to the ground|she wrestled the keys out of the ignition|for over a year David wrestled with a guilty conscience|a wrestle to the death|a lifelong wrestle with depression|

--Word--|wright |--Type--|noun, proper noun|--Meanings--|A maker or builder.|A carpenter or joiner.|Orville (1871–1948) and Wilbur (1867–1912), American aviation pioneers. In 1903 the Wright brothers were the first to make brief powered sustained and controlled flights in an aeroplane, which they had designed and built themselves. They were also the first to make and fly a fully practical powered aeroplane (1905) and a passenger-carrying aeroplane (1908).|--Examples--|
--Word--|wright |--Type--|noun, proper noun|--Meanings--|A maker or builder.|A carpenter or joiner.|Orville (1871–1948) and Wilbur (1867–1912), American aviation pioneers. In 1903 the Wright brothers were the first to make brief powered sustained and controlled flights in an aeroplane, which they had designed and built themselves. They were also the first to make and fly a fully practical powered aeroplane (1905) and a passenger-carrying aeroplane (1908).|--Examples--|

--Word--|write |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Mark (letters, words, or other symbols) on a surface, typically paper, with a pen, pencil, or similar implement.|Have the ability to mark coherent letters or words.|Fill in or complete (a sheet, cheque, or similar)|Take (an exam or test)|Write in a cursive hand, as opposed to printing individual letters.|Compose, write, and send (a letter) to someone.|Write and send a letter to.|Write to an organization, newspaper, etc. with a question, suggestion, or opinion.|Compose (a text or work) for written or printed reproduction or publication; put into literary form and set down in writing.|Compose (a musical work)|Add or remove a character to or from (a long-running story or series).|Describe in writing.|Enter (data) into a specified storage medium or location in store.|Underwrite (an insurance policy).|--Examples--|he wrote his name on the paper|Alice wrote down the address|he wrote very neatly in blue ink|he couldn't read or write|he had to write a cheque for £800|I wrote Prof. Weldon's Middle English exam last week|I wrote a letter to Alison|I wrote him a short letter|he wrote almost every day|Eleanor wrote to her sister Laura in Paris|Mother wrote me and told me about poor Simon's death|write in with your query|she wrote a bestselling novel|I didn't know you wrote poetry|he wrote under a pseudonym|he had written about the beauty of Andalusia|he has written a song specifically for her|if I could write the beauty of your eyes|files can be read and written directly into the file system|

--Word--|write-off |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A vehicle or other object that is too badly damaged to be repaired.|A worthless or ineffectual person or thing.|A cancellation from an account of a bad debt or worthless asset.|--Examples--|the passengers were unharmed, but my car was a total write-off|the magazine was a write-off, its credibility rating below zero|their profits are weakening thanks to loan write-offs|

--Word--|wrong |--Type--|adjective, adverb, noun, verb|--Meanings--|Not correct or true; incorrect.|Having judged incorrectly; mistaken.|Unsuitable or undesirable.|In a bad or abnormal condition; amiss.|Unjust, dishonest, or immoral.|In an unsuitable or undesirable manner or direction.|With an incorrect result.|An unjust, dishonest, or immoral act.|Act unjustly or dishonestly towards.|Mistakenly attribute bad motives to; misrepresent.|--Examples--|that is the wrong answer|I was wrong about him being on the yacht that evening|the doctor may regard the patient's decision as wrong|something was wrong with the pump|that was wrong of me|they were wrong to take the law into their own hands|what am I doing wrong?|she guessed wrong|I have done you a great wrong|I was trying to teach my children right from wrong|they would kill a man who wronged a family|perhaps I wrong him|

--Word--|wrought iron |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A tough malleable form of iron suitable for forging or rolling rather than casting, obtained by puddling pig iron while molten. It is nearly pure but contains some slag in the form of filaments.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Wuhan |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|A port in east central China, the capital of Hubei province; population 8,001,500 (est. 2006). Situated at the confluence of the Han and the Yangtze Rivers, it is a conurbation consisting of three adjacent towns (Hankow, Hanyang, and Wuchang), administered jointly since 1950.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Ulfilas |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(c.311–c.381), bishop and translator. Believed to be of Cappadocian descent, he became bishop of the Visigoths in 341. His translation of the Bible from Greek into Gothic (of which fragments survive) is the earliest known translation of the Bible into a Germanic language. Ulfilas is traditionally held to have invented the Gothic alphabet, based on Latin and Greek characters.|--Examples--|
